frqParts.text: Read each part carefully. Show all your work for each part of the question. The parts within the question may not have equal weight. Figure 1 shows a region of space with four point charges A, B, C, and D that lie in the plane of the screen. The dotted circle represents the cross-section of a spherical Gaussian surface centered on the origin. The spherical Gaussian surface has a radius <math alttext="r" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>r</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> that can be varied. A graph that represents the net electric flux through the spherical Gaussian surface as a function of its radius is shown in Figure 2. (a) State which of the charges is/are positive and which is/are negative. Justify your answer.
(b) Rank the magnitudes of the charges from highest to lowest. If any two charges have the same magnitude, explicitly state this. Justify your ranking using a physics principle or law.
Suppose that the charge C at the origin is now removed for parts (c), (d), and (e).(c) Describe how this would change the graph shown in Figure 2. Be as specific as possible.

(d) Which of the following best describes the direction of the electric field at the origin: (<math alttext="positive x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="positive y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>), (<math alttext="positive x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="negative y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>), (<math alttext="negative x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="positive y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>+</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>), or (<math alttext="negative x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="negative y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mo>−</mo><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>). Justify your answer.
(e) State whether the electric potential at the origin is positive, negative, or zero. Justify your answer.

The remaining charges are removed and replaced with a nonconducting slab that has thickness <math alttext="2 D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>2</mn><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> centered on the origin. The slab is very long in the <math alttext="y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> directions so that the slab is bounded by the planes <math alttext="x equals , negative D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>−</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="x equals , positive D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo>=</mo><mo>+</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. The charge density of the slab does not vary with <math alttext="y" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> or <math alttext="z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and is symmetrical about the <math alttext="y z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-plane. Consider also a Gaussian surface in the form of a rectangular prism whose edges are parallel to the coordinate axes. The width of the surface in the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-direction is <math alttext="w" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>w</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>, the bottom face of the box is coplanar with the <math alttext="y z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-plane, and the left face of the box is coplanar with the <math alttext="y z" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>y</mi><mi>z</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-plane. Figure 3 shows a view of the slab and Gaussian surface from a perspective view, while Figure 4 shows a side view of the slab and Gaussian surface. (f) A student claims that the only face of the Gaussian surface through which flux passes is the right face. Explain why this claim is correct.

(g) The electric field strength along the <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>-axis as a function of <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is shown in the graph above. Based on the shape of the graph, does the charge density in the slab increase, decrease, or remain constant with increasing <math alttext="x" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> for <math alttext="x is less than D" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mi>x</mi><mo><</mo><mi>D</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>? Explain your reasoning using a physics principle or law.
